Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Genetic Mechanisms of Spatial Eco-Evolutionary Dynamics in Range Expansions
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed research will analyze genomic patterns to test evolutionary contributions to experimental range expansion using a model laboratory system. Recent decades have seen large scale changes of species' geographic ranges, as introductions of invasive species and shifting climate patterns displace organisms from ancestral areas and expand into new regions. Many previous models of range movement rely only on ecological processes while ignoring evolution; recent research, however, suggests that evolution at the expanding range edge might play a key role. Range shifts have important conservation and economic implications that will be informed by these studies. The researchers also conduct a workshop course for K-12 teachers and provide curriculum materials to examine range shifts as a teaching tool.

Several hypotheses will be tested by quantifying patterns in allele frequencies through space and time using flour beetles stored from an already completed laboratory range expansion experiment. The hypotheses to be tested are that (1) core and edge locations of a species range should grow increasingly genetically distinct through time, (2) they should accumulate different genetic variants, with edges containing variants associated with high colonization ability, and (3) the speed of range expansion should correlate with these evolved genetic patterns. Whole genome sequencing will be used to quantify allele frequencies among beetles sampled at different times and locations during the range expansion. The results will not only provide insights into the role of spatial structure in evolution, but they will also have significance for management of invasive species and species shifting ranges due to climate change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

Range expansion, or the spatial spread of a species into new territory, is a fundamental biological process crucial to predicting the impact of invasive species, the potential responses of populations to climate change, and the success or failure of species reintroductions. While previous research has elucidated the behavior of range expansions on average, it is important to understand the variance associated with the process as well. Any single range expansion in nature represents the culmination of hundreds or thousands of single, random events, meaning that the observed outcome could have been different were it to be repeated again. To predict the dynamics of future range expansions, it is therefore critical to understand the scope of variance associated with the process. Previous research has demonstrated that the random (i.e. stochastic) nature of range expansions leads to much greater variance in expansion dynamics than predicted by common, purely demographic models of spread. In our research, we used laboratory populations of the red flour beetle, Tribolium castaneum, in experimental landscapes to test the impact of evolution on the variance of range expansions.

The Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant awarded to us by the National Science Foundation has allowed us to expand our research in several important ways. By using the funding to sequence DNA from beetles in our experimental populations, we have been able to identify some of the evolutionary mechanisms at play during range expansion. Crucially, we were able to provide conclusive evidence of a recently theorized mechanism known as gene surfing in which the stochastic events characterizing the range expansion process allow neutral and even harmful genetic variants to reach high frequencies at the edge of the expansion (i.e. “surf” to high frequencies on the expansion wave). The evidence we provided for this mechanism is important for two reasons: (1) it is the first evidence for the strength of gene surfing over the short time scales relevant to contemporary range expansions and (2) our experimental design allowed us to directly link the action of gene surfing to the increased variance in range expansion speeds observed in our experimental landscapes. Our results, therefore, suggest that the process of gene surfing can propagate stochastic effects from the genomic level to the level of population dynamics across the landscape and should be considered in predictions of range expansions in nature.

Broader impacts

The results from this project are highly relevant to efforts in conservation biology to predict the spread rates of invasive species or the potential success of species moving in response to climate change. Our work shows that such predictions must take into account evolutionary processes as rapid evolution, particularly gene surfing, can lead to higher than expected variance in spread rates. Without accounting for such processes, predictions of spatial spread may risk underestimating the uncertainty in spread rates.

A graduate student received mentoring and gained valuable professional skills through this project. This project also provided valuable, first-hand experience of the scientific process and cutting edge genetic techniques for an undergraduate student.

This was a one year grant, and there has thus not yet been enough time for all of the results to be published. We have presented results at a national conference and will soon present at more national conferences. We will submit several manuscripts to high impact, general interest journals.
